III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 7/31/25, a staff member left medications unattended as they
walked away from the table two to three times. A youth took the
bubble packs containing medications and consumed their
prescribed medication. The youth ingested one Seroquel and one
Clonidine. This youth has a history of overdosing requiring
hospitalization. There is a safety plan for all medication to be
monitored around this youth.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted via email on August 5, 2025, and
reported they had no additional information.
Youth was interviewed via telephone on August 4, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth said she has been
placed at Zonta house since the end of July 2025. Youth said she
feels safe at Zonta house and is currently on “safe status” for
suicide watch. Youth said the staff at Zonta house pass her
medications each morning and evening. Youth said “on Thursday”
she was very upset with Staff 1 because he “lied on” two peers,
telling nursing they refused their medications when they did not
refuse. Youth said wanted her nighttime medications so she could
go to bed and Staff 1 “was taking too long” to provide them to her.
Youth said Staff 1 left the medications unattended “a couple times”
to go to the snack cabinet and do a check on a youth in a
bedroom. Youth said her medications were on the dining room
table, so she took her “pack of medication” and took her nighttime
medications while Staff 1 was in the kitchen. Youth said Staff 1
saw her and asked her to give the medications back to him and
she refused and walked outside. Youth said Staff 1 and Staff 2
followed her outside and watched her. Youth said she eventually
gave them the medications and came back inside. Youth said this
is the first time staff have left medications unattended during her
time at Zonta house. Youth said she took the medications because
she was mad at Staff 1. Youth said she does not know if she has a
safety plan or what it entails.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on August 4, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 said he is a direct
2

care staff and has been employed at Whaley Children’s Center
since February 2025. Staff 1 said he works in Zonta house with
Youth. Staff 1 said Youth recently moved to Zonta house and had
been doing well overall and he felt he had a good relationship with
Youth. Staff 1 said during his shift on July 31, 2025, Youth
befriended another youth and they began to “gang up on him”
throughout the shift turning everything he said to them the wrong
way and getting more and more upset as the day went on. Staff 1
said Staff 2 came into work around medication time however it
was decided he would pass Youth’s evening medications. Staff 1
said Youth refused her medications and he did not push her but
rather said “ok” and let her have space. Staff 1 said he left with
another youth for a period of time and upon his return to Zonta
house Staff 2 told him he needed to pass Youth’s medications and
pulled it all out to the table and then walked back to the couch.
Staff 1 said he walked over to the snack cabinet with the
medication box and then went back to the dining room table and
sat down. Staff 1 said he began to get Youth’s medications
prepared for distribution when Youth walked over and grabbed two
medication packs and walked to the back of the house. Staff 1
said he asked Youth to give him back the medications and he
refused so he asked Staff 2 for assistance in retrieving the
medications. Staff 1 said Youth walked outside and he followed
her. Staff 1 said he and Staff 2 switched and she stayed outside
with Youth while he returned inside. Staff 1 said he called
Supervisor to notify him and ask for guidance and assistance.
Staff 1 said he witnessed Youth take one medication prior to
Supervisor arriving and getting all medications away from Youth.
Staff 1 said he did a medication count which revealed Youth took
one pill from each bubble pack which is her normal evening
dosage. Staff 1 said his understanding of the medication
administration policy is staff are to get medications prepared away
from youth and sign the medication log as medications are
popped and placed in a cup, call the youth to the table, provide
the youth medications with water, and do a mouth check to ensure
they have taken the medications. Staff 1 denied the medication
policy requiring medications to be prepared and passed in a
locked or secure area, noting the youth are supposed to stay an
arm length away from staff when they have the medications out.
Staff 1 said medications are stored in a locked closet in the
hallway. Staff 1 said that day was very difficult for him as Youth
and her peers had been verbally abusing him throughout the day.
Staff 1 said Youth has a safety plan that prevents her from going
to the main campus to receive her medication from the nursing
staff. Staff 1 denied being aware of any other safety plan for
Youth.
3

Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
6, 2025. Staff 2 said she was working the evening of July 31,
2025, with Staff 1. Staff 2 said Staff 1 took Youth’s medication box
to the dining room with Youth present. Staff 2 said she was in the
living room with other youth. Staff 2 said she did not see what took
place in the dining room. Staff 2 said Youth walked into the living
room and had two bubble packs of medication in her hand. Staff 2
said she asked Youth to give her the medications, and she refused
and walked outside. Staff 2 said she followed Youth outside and
was talking with her and asking her to give her the medication
packs. Staff 2 said Supervisor pulled into the driveway and was
able to talk with Youth and get the medication packs from her.
Staff 2 said she sat outside and talked with Youth who reported
that Staff 1 had stepped away from the medications and so she
grabbed them and walked away. Staff 2 said normally works third
shift and does not pass medication and so wanted Staff 1 to pass
the medications as he is used to having to do it on second shift.
Staff 2 said Youth is on a safety plan and cannot go to main
campus to get her medication. Staff 2 said she is not confident in
all of the steps of medication administration, but she does know
that staff are not supposed to ever leave medications unattended.
Staff 2 said the medications are kept in a locked closet and
normally prepped by staff at the dining room table. Staff 2 said
staff will call youth one by one to get any medication they are
prescribed.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
6, 2025. Staff 3 said all medications are locked in the hallway
closet. Staff 3 said the normal medication passing procedure is for
staff to get the youth’s medication box out of the closet and take it
to the dining room table where they review and pull the
appropriate medications and place the medication in a small cup
and then either take the medication to the youth for them to take
them or have the youth come to the table to take the medications.
Staff 3 said the medications are never left unattended and that
youth are never allowed to be within arm’s length of the
medications as they are out on the table. Staff 3 said if there are
issues within the house with youth behaviors then the medications
should not be brought out into the dining room or if there becomes
an issue while the medications are out then they are to be put
away immediately. Staff 3 said should this occur, the nurses would
be notified and either assist in medication passing or give
directives on how the staff should proceed with medication
passing. Staff 3 said she had been informed of the incident on July
31, 2025, and stated Youth’s medications should have never been
4

brought into the dining room given the fact that she was escalated
at the time.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
August 6, 2025. Supervisor said Staff 1 called him on July 31,
2025, and told him that Youth had taken medication packs when
he was preparing to pass her medications and would not give
them back to staff. Supervisor said he immediately went to Zonta
house and upon his arrival Youth was outside and gave two
medication bubble packs to him right away. Supervisor said Youth
told him she took one pill out of each pack, and he did a
medication count with Staff 1 which confirmed her statement.
Supervisor said he directed Staff 1 to secure Youth’s medications,
and he did. Supervisor said he then returned to main campus.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
August 6, 2025. Therapist said she has been working with Youth
since July 23, 2025. Therapist said Youth was placed at Mott
Children’s Residence and recently moved to Zonta house.
Therapist said there was a safety plan that was written prior to her
becoming Youth’s therapist and then since then there was a
separation plan in place for Youth and a peer at Mott Children’s
Residence due to inappropriate boundaries which prohibits Youth
from going to the main campus.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of July 31, 2025, dining room area, was
reviewed on August 5, 2025. Staff 1 is sitting at the dining room
table with seven bubble packs of pills, a white bag, serval papers,
and a bottle of water in front of him. Youth is seen entering the
dining room and taking the white bag, opening it, and taking a box
out of the bag and turning to the right so the front part of her body
and hands are off camera. Youth turns further around, and she is
seen shaking an inhaler and then putting it to her mouth, Staff 1
stands up and walks a few feet closer to her, leaving all the other
medications on the table. Youth places the inhaler back in the box
and tosses it towards the table and it goes across the table onto
the floor. Staff 1 reaches down to pick it up and Youth grabs two
bubble packs of pills and walks out of the room. Staff 1 follows
Youth, leaving the other medications unattended on the table.
Youth walks back into the room by the table grabs the bottle of
water and walks out of camera view. Staff 1 is seen on his phone
and follows Youth out of camera view, leaving all other
medications on the table unattended. Youth reenters the dining
room with Staff 1 following her and grabs another bubble pack and
then throws it back onto the table. Youth exits camera view, Staff 1
5

walks to table and puts the other bubble packs in a pile but then
leaves them on the table and follows another youth out of the
room leaving a third youth in the dining room unattended with the
medications on the table. Staff 1 reenters the dining room and
then exits, medications still unattended on the table for about 20
seconds, then reenters the room and walks to the medications
and picks them all up and places them in the box and takes the
box with the medications off camera view. Youth returns into the
dining room with the two bubble packs in her hand, Staff 1 comes
back into the dining room and is watching her, Youth exits the
room, Staff 1 follows her.
Documents Reviewed:
• Staff 1’ personnel file: There was disciplinary action dated
May 12, 2025, for failure to comply with training. Staff 1
completed medication passing training during New Hire
Orientation on February 14, 2025.
• Whaley Children’s Center Incident Reports dated July 31,
2025, regarding Youth A was reviewed. The first incident
report was regarding Youth A’s actions leading up to
medication passing which clearly indicated she was
dysregulated and is consistent with Staff 1’s interview. The
second incident report was regarding Youth A taking the
medications which was written by Staff 1 and is consistent
with his interview.
• Whaley Children’s Center Medication Policy was reviewed.
The policy outlines the medication administration procedure
and clearly states “Never leave medications unattended”. In
addition, the normal practice for medication passing is “all
of the medication passes for the child and youth will take
place at the medical office”.
• Whaley Children’s Center Safety Plan for Youth was
reviewed. The safety plan is dated May 14, 2025, and
provides background information on Youth specifically
stating “[Youth] attempted to overdose on Tylenol, resulting
in her current hospitalization”. The plan reviews precautions
that staff must take with Youth including “[Youth] also has a
history of ‘cheeking’ medications, and any medication
distribution should be closely monitored”.
• Youth’s Separation Plan dated June 6, 2025, was
reviewed. The separation plan indicates Youth must be on
a “level 2 separation” from another youth. The level 2
separation is defined for staff and provides maximum
separation at all times due to allegations, precaution, and
inappropriate boundaries between Youth and a peer.
6

Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per Youth’s and staff
interviews, video review, and documentation review, Staff 1 did
not follow the agency’s policy regarding medication administration
and left medications unattended resulting in Youth having access
to take her medication packs.
Technical Assistance:
It is recommended the staff prepare all medications in a locked
area and do not take youth’s entire monthly supply of medication
into an open uncontrolled area. Further, it is recommended the
medication distribution also occurs from a controlled or locked
area such as the Zonta house locked laundry room. If this is not
possible, then it is recommended the nurses prepare the
medications in their locked area and transport the individual doses
to the Zonta house and pass the medications to the youth at the
Zonta house.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
